title-group.article-title: Central Role of GABA in Neuron–Glia Interactions

article-meta.aff: 4Division of Neurophysiology, The National Institute for Medical Research, Mill Hill, UK

author-notes.corresp: María Cecilia Angulo, Laboratoire de Neurophysiologie et Nouvelles Microscopies, Inserm U603, CNRS UMR 8154, Université Paris Descartes, 45, rue des Saints-Pères, 75006 Paris, France Email: maria-cecilia.angulo@parisdescartes.fr

abstract.p: The major types of glial cells—astrocytes, microglia, and cells of the oligodendroglial lineage—are known to express functional metabotropic and ionotropic GABA receptors. Neuronal signaling mechanisms allowing for the activation of these receptors in glia are probably as complex as those described among neurons and involve synaptic and extrasynaptic transmission modes. In addition, astrocytes can signal back to neurons by releasing GABA, probably through unconventional nonvesicular mechanisms. The decryption of the roles played by GABAergic signaling in neuron–glia interactions is only beginning, but it has been suggested that activation of glial cells by GABA influences important functions of the brain such as neuronal activity, differentiation, myelination, and neuroprotection. This review discusses the cellular mechanisms allowing the major types of glial cells to sense and transmit GABAergic signals and gives an overview of potential roles of this signaling pathway in developing and mature brains.

body.p: In the brain, presynaptic and postsynaptic neurons form complex and sophisticated networks that compute the information underlying perception and cognition. However, the “neurocentric” assumption that neurons conduct and process all the information by themselves has been questioned in the last 20 years. There is now strong evidence demonstrating that neuronal network information also flows toward glia, which express many of the same receptors for neurotransmitters as neurons and respond to neuronal activity. Although the precise decoding of neuron–glia interactions in brain function is not yet known, glial cell activation may contribute to synapse formation, cell development, myelination, brain microcirculation, neuroprotection, and modulation of neuronal activity (see Barres 2008 for a review). Contrary to the classical view that glial cells are subordinated to neurons, neurons and glia probably undertake concerted actions in the brain without a hierarchical relationship.

Glutamate and GABA are the two major neurotransmitters of the brain. Whereas the role of glutamate in neuron–glia interactions has been at the center of consideration for two decades, the interest in GABA has become stronger only recently as evidenced by the increasing number of publications in the last few years. Indeed, it is more and more likely that major classes of glial cells (astrocytes, microglia, and cells of the oligodendroglial lineage) express ionotropic GABAA and metabotropic GABAB receptors in vivo and that the activation of these receptors contributes to multiple functional roles. It has also been shown that astrocytes can signal back to neurons by releasing GABA through unconventional nonvesicular mechanisms (see Angulo and others 2008 for a review; Lee and others 2010). In this review, we highlight recent findings on the cellular mechanisms allowing glial cells to sense and transmit GABAergic signals, and we discuss the potential roles of this signaling pathway in developing and mature brains.

sec.title: Reciprocal GABAergic Communication between Neurons and Astrocytes
sec.p: The classical roles of astrocytes include the supply of neurons with metabolic support and the removal from the synaptic cleft of products resulting from neuronal activity. However, astrocytes are also engaged in a reciprocal signaling with neurons that allows them to contribute actively to information processing by regulating neuronal activity. Among the reciprocal signaling molecules between neurons and astrocytes, glutamate, D-serine, and ATP have been studied the most (see Perea and others 2009 for a review). Yet, a large body of evidence indicates that astrocytes are sensitive to and can release GABA.

sec.title: Neuron-to-Astrocyte Communication Mediated by GABAA Receptors
sec.p: The functional expression of GABA receptors in astrocytes was first described in culture, where it was reported that GABA depolarizes through the activation of GABAA receptors (Kettenmann and others 1984; Kettenmann and Schachner 1985). These receptors have unitary conductances and gating properties similar to those recorded in neurons but different pharmacological properties of their benzodiazepine site (Bormann and Kettenmann 1988; Rosewater and Sontheimer 1994). Indeed, instead of being inhibited by the inverse benzodiazepine agonist methyl-4-ethyl-6,7-dimethoxy-β-carboline-3-carboxylate (DMCM), GABAA receptor–mediated currents in astrocytes are enhanced by this molecule, suggesting a specific subunit composition. Although this subunit composition has not been firmly established yet, immunohistochemical studies have revealed the presence of at least α1 and β1 on hippocampal astrocytes (Fraser and others 1995) and of α2 and γ1 on Bergmann glia (Riquelme and others 2002).

Initial observations showing a depolarizing effect of GABAA receptor activation on cultured astrocytes were largely confirmed in hippocampal, retinal, and hypothalamic astrocytes; retinal Muller cells; and cerebellar Bergmann glia (Fig. 1; Clark and Mobbs 1992; Fraser and others 1995; Israel and others 2003; MacVicar and others 1989; Malchow and others 1989; Meier and others 2008; Muller and others 1994; Steinhauser and others 1994). The GABAA receptor–mediated depolarization of astrocyte is probably due to a relatively high intracellular Cl− concentration that leads to an efflux of this anion when GABAA receptors are activated from the very negative resting membrane potential of these cells (Kettenmann 1990; Kimelberg 1990). Contrary to neurons, the depolarizing effect of astrocytic GABAA receptors persists throughout postnatal development, although the response may attenuate with age (Bekar and others 1999; Bernstein and others 1996; Butt and Jennings 1994a; but see Meier and others 2008).

sec.p: The role of GABAA receptor–mediated responses in astrocytes is intriguing because these cells do not produce action potentials or even efficiently propagate depolarizations. A first possibility is that changes in membrane potential are not important but that the intracellular Cl− concentration modulates the activity of potassium channels in astrocytes (Fig. 2A; Bekar and others 1999). Another possibility comes from the observation that GABAA receptor–induced depolarization leads to intracellular Ca2+ elevation in these cells through the activation of voltage-gated calcium channels (VGCCs; Figs. 1 and 2A; Bernstein and others 1996; Fraser and others 1995; Meier and others 2008; Nilsson and others 1993). Considering that intracellular Ca2+ signaling represents a form of excitability used by astrocytes to integrate neuronal activity (Perea and others 2009), GABA-mediated depolarization may be an important pathway through which GABAergic neurons influence astrocytic functions. It should be noted, however, that GABAA receptor activation in astrocytes by endogenously released GABA has not been reported. Thus, we cannot totally rule out the possibility that the depolarizing action of these responses is a consequence of prolonged exposures to exogenously applied agonists that can artificially shift the Cl− equilibrium toward positive values. Regardless of the ability (or not) of endogenous GABA to induce intracellular Ca2+ increases, the absence of phasic GABAA receptor activation in astrocytes may suggest that the role of these receptors is not to integrate neuronal activity on a short time scale but rather to monitor local concentrations of ambient GABA. Interestingly, GABA released by neuroblasts in the subventricular zone is responsible for a GABAA receptor–mediated tonic current, which in turn controls the proliferation of astrocyte-like GFAP-expressing progenitors (Liu and others 2005). By analogy with these progenitors, astrocytes may be sensitive to ambient rather than to local and transient GABA. In this sense, in vitro and in vivo experiments have shown that the morphological differentiation of astrocytes, in particular the number of processes and degree of branching, is controlled by prolonged GABAA receptor activation, both during development and in the adult (Matsutani and Yamamoto 1997; Mong and others 2002; Runquist and Alonso 2003).

caption.p: Schematic diagram of proposed GABAergic signaling pathways in glial cells. (A) Astrocytes express GABAA, GABAB receptors, and GABA transporters (GATs), activation of which can induce intracellular Ca2+ increases. First, GABAA–receptor activation causes a depolarization that is large enough to reach the threshold of voltage-gated calcium channels (VGCCs), leading to a Ca2+ influx from the extracellular space. However, the main role of GABAA receptor–mediated depolarization has not been completely established. It could be to modulate the activity of potassium channels rather than induce Ca2+ increases. It is also noteworthy that physiological conditions required to activate GABAA receptors in astrocytes are still elusive. Second, the selective activation of GABAB receptors leads to intracellular Ca2+ elevations, probably by inducing a Ca2+ release from intracellular IP3-sensitive Ca2+ stores. Finally, the uptake of GABA by mGAT4 is accompanied by an influx of Na+ that causes a reduction of the extrusion of Ca2+ from Na+/Ca2+ exchangers (NCXs). (B) Microglia expresses GABAB receptors that induce both an outwardly rectifying K+ current and intracellular Ca2+ elevations. (C) Oligodendrocyte precursor cells (OPCs) express metabotropic and ionotropic GABA receptors. As for astrocytes, applications of GABAA receptor agonists induce a depolarization accompanied by an increase in intracellular Ca2+ concentration. Two controversial mechanisms responsible for this Ca2+ elevation have been proposed: (i) GABAA receptor–mediated depolarization activates VGCCs, leading to a Ca2+ influx into the cytosol; (ii) membrane depolarization activates a persistent Na+ current, which in turn causes a Ca2+ entry through the reversed activity of the NCX1. OPCs receive GABAergic synaptic input from neurons in young mice (1); this input is lost during postnatal development and replaced by an extrasynaptic mode of communication, mediated solely by local GABA spillover (2). GABAA receptors of OPCs can thus be activated either synaptically or extrasynaptically according to the developmental stage, but it is unknown whether these activation modes induce Ca2+ increases. Finally, the mechanisms of GABAB receptor activation and the resulting intracellular signaling pathways are unknown.

sec.title: Neuron-to-Astrocyte Communication Mediated by GABAB Receptors
sec.p: GABAB receptors are G-protein–coupled receptors that often modulate the activity of calcium and potassium channels in neurons. In astrocytes, immunohistochemical analyses have demonstrated that the three major subunits forming these heterodimeric receptors, GABAB1a, GABAB1b, and GABAB2, are present in processes surrounding symmetrical and asymmetrical synapses of the hippocampus and the periaqueductal gray matter (Barbaresi 2007; Charles and others 2003). Whereas early studies based on electrophysiological approaches failed to detect the functional expression of GABAB receptors in astrocytes (Bekar and others 1999; Butt and Jennings 1994b; Kettenmann and Schachner 1985), Ca2+ imaging experiments clearly demonstrated that selective GABAB receptor activation leads to an intracellular Ca2+ increase in these cells (Kang and others 1998; Meier and others 2008; Nilsson and others 1993; Serrano and others 2006). Most likely, GABAB receptor activation does not directly modulate membrane channels but induces a release of Ca2+ from intracellular IP3-sensitive Ca2+ stores (Fig. 2A; Meier and others 2008).

In hippocampal slices, astrocytic GABAB receptors can be activated by endogenous GABA during repetitive stimulations of a single inhibitory interneuron (Kang and others 1998). Serrano and others (2006) and Andersson and others (2007) recently showed that the signaling pathway involving GABAergic interneurons and astrocytic GABAB receptors plays a pivotal role in heterosynaptic depression. This form of synaptic plasticity occurs at inactive synapses located in the vicinity of synapses potentiated during tetanus stimulation. It is an NMDA receptor–dependent process and requires the activation of local GABAergic interneurons (Manzoni and others 1994) and the release of ATP by astrocytes (Pascual and others 2005; Zhang and others 2003). The prevention of GABAB receptor–mediated Ca2+ increases, and the subsequent release of ATP by either blocking GABAB receptors or chelating Ca2+ in astrocytes inhibits the induction of heterosynaptic depression (Andersson and others 2007; Serrano and others 2006).

The above-mentioned studies have clearly established that GABAB receptors allow astrocytes to integrate and modulate complex patterns of neuronal activity in the hippocampus. Yet, several questions remain to be clarified. First, only a minority of astrocytes respond to GABAB receptor stimulation, and this response is developmentally regulated (Meier and others 2008). It is therefore important to study the functional expression of these receptors in other brain regions and at different developmental stages. Second, interactions between GABAB receptors and other signaling pathways have been rarely studied in astrocytes (but see Meier and others 2008), but patterns of neuronal network activities during which astrocytic GABAB receptors are mobilized are also known to activate metabotropic glutamate receptors. It would be interesting to know how these two pathways interact in astrocytes when they are simultaneously activated. In addition, it would be important to determine the patterns of neuronal activity required to activate GABAA receptors in physiological conditions.

sec.title: Neuron-to-Astrocyte Communication Mediated by GABA Transporters
sec.p: Besides GABA receptors, astrocytes express GABA transporters (GATs) whose main role is to remove the neurotransmitter from the synaptic cleft. Doengi and others (2009) recently described that in addition to this well-established function of GATs, these transporters have a role in astrocytic Ca2+ elevations in response to GABA applications or electrical stimulations of sensory neuron axons in the olfactory bulb (Fig. 2A). Interestingly, GABA receptors do not seem to play a major role in neuron-to-astrocyte signaling in this structure. The uptake of GABA by GATs is accompanied by an influx of Na+ that causes a reduction of the extrusion of Ca2+ by Na+/Ca2+ exchangers (NCXs), also expressed in astrocytes (Fig. 2A). The subsequent accumulation of Ca2+ in the cytosol leads to a Ca2+-induced Ca2+ release from IP3-sensitive intracellular stores, amplifying the Ca2+ signal. The precise function of this pathway is not completely understood, but neuron-to-astrocyte signaling via GATs may participate to the control of the bulbar vascular tone (Doengi and others 2009). Indeed, the blockade of mGAT4, the murine form of GATs expressed by astrocytes, inhibits the vasoconstriction that occurs upon GABA application. These results are reminiscent of the role of astrocytic glutamate transporters regulating blood flow (see Attwell and others 2010 for a review) and point to a new mechanism through which inhibitory neuronal networks communicate with astrocytes.

sec.title: Modulation of Neuronal Activity by GABA Release from Astrocytes
sec.p: It is now widely acknowledged that astrocytes release different transmitters, among which glutamate, ATP, and D-serine have received much attention (see Perea and others 2009 for a review). Yet, there are also numerous data supporting a role of GABA as a gliotransmitter. We have recently reviewed the experimental evidence of the literature for GABA accumulation, production, and release by glial cells (Angulo and others 2008). In this section we focus on functional studies revealing how GABA released from astrocytes modulates neuronal activity in situ (i.e., not in culture).

The first evidence in favor of a role of astrocytic GABA release in modulating neuronal activity comes from studies performed on ex vivo preparation of the optic nerve, a structure devoid of neuronal cell bodies. Sakatani and others (1991) demonstrated that either exogenously applied GABA or GABA uptake inhibitors increase the latency of compound action potentials in neonatal but not adult animals. Importantly, GABAA receptor antagonists decrease the action potential latency, indicating a tonic activation of these receptors by endogenous GABA release (Sakatani and others 1991). This transient effect of GABA in the developing optic nerve perfectly coincides with a transient content of this transmitter in astrocytes, suggesting an astrocytic origin of ambient GABA (Lake 1992; Ochi and others 1993). However, a formal demonstration of GABA release from astrocytes in the optic nerve is still missing and is controversial. Other sources of GABA cannot be totally excluded because some axons of the optic nerve contain this neurotransmitter (Rogers and Pow 1995; Sakatani and others 1992) and because vesicular release of glutamate onto glial cells in white matter regions has been reported (see Maldonado and others 2011 for a review).

Recent studies have provided a more straightforward demonstration of GABA release from astrocytes and its effect on generating phasic or tonic GABAA receptor activation in neurons. In the adult olfactory bulb, spontaneous nonsynaptic GABA release induces slow GABAA receptor–mediated transient currents that inhibit the action potential firing of mitral and granule cells (Kozlov and others 2006). These spontaneous slow currents can be evoked upon mechanical stimulation of astrocytes and are synchronized in pairs of mitral cells, in pairs of granule cells, and in pairs of mitral and granule cells recorded simultaneously at a distance of less than 100 µm. Interestingly, the analysis of this synchronization indicates that a single astrocyte is responsible for synchronous currents in neighboring neurons (Kozlov and others 2006). Moreover, the observation that astrocyte-mediated synchronization of mitral cells occurs even in cells that do not project to the same glomerulus suggests that astrocytic control of neuronal activity operates on a different level than that of the synaptic organization of the neuronal network (Kozlov and others 2006). This idea is consistent with morphological analyses indicating that neighboring astrocytes occupy nonoverlapping territories (Bushong and others 2002; Ogata and Kosaka 2002).

In the cerebellum, Lee and others (2010) recently reported that GABA is present and released from Bergmann glia via the anion-permeable channel bestrophin-1. This mechanism of release through an anion channel is similar to the mechanism suggested for the astrocytic release of GABA in the olfactory bulb (Kozlov and others 2006). It is worth noting that nonvesicular mechanisms have been proposed for other gliotransmitters, including glutamate (see Hamilton and Attwell 2010 for a review). GABA release from Bergmann glia was found to be responsible for a large part of the tonic activation of GABAA receptors observed in granule cells (Lee and others 2010). This tonic current had been characterized previously by several groups and was shown to be action potential independent (at least partially) and of nonvesicular origin (see, e.g., Wall and Usowicz 1997). This tonic GABAA receptor–mediated current modulates the integrative properties of cerebellar granule cells in vivo (Chadderton and others 2004). Similar tonic GABAA receptor–mediated currents have been recorded in acute slices in other central neurons and could thus be generated by GABA released from astrocytes. However, this hypothesis should be tested carefully because a synaptic contribution has been clearly demonstrated for tonic GABAA receptor–mediated currents in thalamic and hippocampal neurons (Bright and others 2007; Glykys and Mody 2007). Nonvesicular release of GABA from neurons could also occur through a reverse operation of GABA transporters (see Richerson and Wu 2003 for a review). Finally, although astrocytes are endowed with the ability to release GABA onto neurons, the demonstration of a presynaptic receptor activation by astrocytic GABA is still missing. Presynaptic GABAA and GABAB receptors are known to regulate neurotransmitter release and could constitute a target of choice for astrocytes to control neuronal network activities (see, e.g., Stell and others 2007 for GABAA receptors).

sec.title: GABA Regulates Microglia Function
sec.p: Microglial cells are the resident macrophages of the CNS that orchestrate the inflammatory reaction occurring during brain injury and disease. The motility of their processes allows them to probe their environment, sense synaptic activity, and detect warning signals in the brain parenchyma, reflecting the presence of pathogens or lesions (see Ransohoff and Perry 2009 for a review). These signals can induce microglial activation, which consists of a profound and adapted change of the phenotype of these cells and determines their influence on the outcome of different diseases (see Hanisch and Kettenmann 2007; Ransohoff and Perry 2009 for reviews). Among different signals affecting microglia physiology, GABA has recently gained increasing interest.

Microglial cells are known to be sensitive to GABAergic signaling mediated by both GABAA and GABAB receptors. However, the functional expression of GABAA receptors on microglia remains controversial. Indeed, bath application of GABAA receptor agonists enhances a K+ current in amoeboid microglial cells in slices of the corpus callosum from neonate rodents, but this effect results from the K+ concentration increase in the extracellular space attributable to the depolarization of neighboring cells (Cheung and others 2009). In the retina of adult rodents, GABA and the GABAA receptor antagonist bicuculline have opposite effects on microglial process dynamics, but these effects appear again to be indirect because no membrane currents are activated in recorded microglia upon GABA applications (Fontainhas and others 2011). Nevertheless, human microglial cells were recently shown to express functional GABAA receptors in cell culture, raising the possibility of their expression in particular conditions (Lee and others 2011).

Whereas GABAA receptor expression in microglial cells is only suggested in one study of cultured cells, immunohistochemical and electrophysiological studies have convincingly shown the presence of GABAB receptors in these cells (Charles and others 2003; Kuhn and others 2004; Lee and others 2011). Activation of these receptors induces an outwardly rectifying K+ current and an increase of the intracellular Ca2+ concentration (Fig. 2B; Kuhn and others 2004). Interestingly, the number of microglia expressing GABAB receptors increases when these cells are activated in pathological conditions (Kuhn and others 2004).

Direct and indirect GABAergic signaling via GABAA and GABAB receptor activation has anti-inflammatory effects by inhibiting lipopolysaccharide- or interferon γ–induced microglia release of interleukin-6, interleukin-12, and tumor necrosis factor-α (Kuhn and others 2004; Lee and others 2011). In addition, the study by Cheung and others (2009) indicates that during normal brain development, GABAA receptor–mediated efflux of K+ from neighboring cells mobilized developing amoeboid microglial cells, favoring the production of macrophage inflammatory protein-1α (MIP-1α). The role of this cytokine during development is still largely unknown, but it has been suggested that MIP-1α modulates the migration and differentiation of neuronal and glial cells (Cowell and Silverstein 2003; Tanabe and others 1997). This is consistent with the idea that microglial cells influence the normal development of neural brain cells (Bessis and others 2007). It is thus very likely that GABA influences microglia functions in both physiological and pathological conditions.

sec.title: Synaptic and Extrasynaptic Transmission between GABAergic Neurons and Cells of the Oligodendroglial Lineage
sec.p: Oligodendrocytes (OLs) are myelin-forming cells of the CNS that derive from oligodendrocyte precursor cells (OPCs) during development. OPCs, also termed NG2 cells or polydendrocytes, among other names (see Nishiyama and others 2009 for a review), persist in the mature brain. In the adult CNS, they constitute the main proliferative cell type that serves as a major source of remyelinating oligodendrocytes in demyelinating diseases. It has been suggested that in addition to being oligodendrocyte precursors, OPCs may be multipotent progenitors endowed with the ability to generate astrocytes and neurons, but this issue is still highly debated (see Nishiyama and others 2009 for a review; Kang and others 2010).

sec.title: Functional Expression of GABAA and GABAB Receptors
sec.p: The first descriptions of functional GABAA receptors, either in OPCs or in OLs, were obtained in explant cultures of spinal cord (Gilbert and others 1984; Hoppe and Kettenmann 1989) and primary cultures of embryonic brain (Von Blankenfeld and others 1991). Bath and local applications of GABAA receptor agonists induced currents in OPCs and OLs that were sensitive to the nonselective GABAA receptor antagonists picrotoxin and bicuculline, indicating the presence of ionotropic GABA receptors resembling those of neurons. Similarly, bath applications of GABA or of the GABAA receptor agonist muscimol also induced bicuculline-sensitive currents in OPCs and OLs recorded in brain slices of corpus callosum (Berger and others 1992) and hippocampus (Steinhauser and others 1994). Yet, the amplitudes of GABAA receptor–mediated currents recorded in OLs in both culture and brain slices were significantly smaller than those recorded in OPCs (Berger and others 1992; Von Blankenfeld and others 1991). The marked amplitude decrease of responses in OLs suggests that OPC differentiation is accompanied by a down-regulation of GABAA receptors, as recently described for ionotropic glutamate receptors in normal conditions during development and after a focal demyelination (De Biase and others 2010; Etxeberria and others 2010; Kukley and others 2010).

Little is known about the subunit composition of GABAA receptors in OPCs. Contradictory results were obtained in cell culture in which benzodiazepine compounds were tested on evoked GABAA receptor–mediated currents. Whereas Von Blankenfeld and others (1991) demonstrated positive and negative allosteric modulations by benzodiazepines, Bronstein and others (1998) and Williamson and others (1998) did not observe any effect. Given that the inclusion of γ subunits, in particular the γ2 subunit, in association with α and β subunits confers benzodiazepine sensitivity (Pritchett and others 1989), these results suggest the presence of γ subunits in experiments carried out by Von Blankenfeld and others (1991) but not in studies by Bronstein and others (1998) and Williamson and others (1998). The absence of benzodiazepine-sensitive receptors in these latter studies was corroborated by single-cell RT-PCR that showed the absence of γ subunit messenger RNAs (mRNAs) in these cells (Bronstein and others 1998). The inhibition of GABAergic currents with bath applications of Zn2+ (100 µM), a blocker of receptors lacking γ2 subunits, also suggests the absence of this subunit (Bronstein and others 1998; Williamson and others 1998). The γ2 subunit is of major interest because it is required for targeting GABAA receptors to GABAergic synapses. Synaptic contacts between inhibitory interneurons and OPCs were described firstly by Lin and Bergles (2004) in acute hippocampal slices (see below). In this study, the benzodiazepine diazepam significantly increased the decay time of miniature GABAA receptor–mediated currents in OPCs, suggesting the presence of γ2 subunits in native receptors at the synapse (Lin and Bergles 2004). However, we recently reported in acute slices of the somatosensory cortex that late in postnatal development, GABAA receptors in OPCs are exclusively extrasynaptic (Vélez-Fort and others 2010). In neurons, extrasynaptic GABAA receptors usually lack γ2 subunits and have a different subunit composition to that of synaptic receptors. It is thus possible that modifications of the expression of GABAA receptor subtypes occur during development as well as in different culture conditions. Further studies aiming at characterizing the pharmacological properties and subunit composition of native GABAA receptors during development are needed.

The functional expression of GABAB receptors was recently reported in cultured CG-4 cell line, a highly homogenous system allowing for the specific analysis of the properties of cells belonging to the oligodendroglial lineage (Luyt and others 2007). RT-PCR and in situ hybridization experiments showed the presence of mRNAs coding for GABAB1 and GABAB2 subunits in OPCs and to a modest extent in CG4-derived OLs. The reduced expression of GABAB subunits in OLs is in agreement with the lack of immunoreactivity for GABAB1 in white matter myelinating oligodendrocytes (Charles and others 2003). As for GABAA receptors, GABAB receptors are thus probably down-regulated during the differentiation process of OPCs.

sec.title: Different Modes of GABAergic Receptor Activation
sec.p: One of the most significant discoveries of the last 10 years in the field of neuron–glia interactions has been the demonstration of true functional synapses between neurons and OPCs (Bergles and others 2000). Since the first studies of Bergles and colleagues, several reports have shown functional glutamatergic and GABAergic synaptic contacts on these cells in different brain regions (see Maldonado and others 2011 for a review). However, although extensive work has been performed on glutamatergic synaptic transmission, the number of studies on GABAergic synapses remains low (Jabs and others 2005; Karadottir and others 2008; Kukley and others 2008; Lin and Bergles 2004; Vélez-Fort and others 2010). Interestingly, synaptic GABAergic currents have been observed in neuronal progenitor cells of the hippocampus, suggesting that this signaling pathway is shared by several precursor cell types (Tozuka and others 2005; Wang and others 2005).

GABAergic synapses of OPCs were initially described in hippocampal slices of juvenile rats, where the kinetics of spontaneous and evoked currents were consistent with a rapid release of neurotransmitter at specialized synaptic contacts, that is, rise times in the submillisecond range and decay times less than 30 ms (Lin and Bergles 2004). As for glutamatergic events, the frequency of spontaneous GABAA receptor–mediated currents is very low in the hippocampus (between 0.017 and 0.05 Hz; Jabs and others 2005; Lin and Bergles 2004) but reaches higher values in deep layers of the somatosensory cortex (~0.7 Hz; Vélez-Fort and others 2010). In the presence of the Na+ channel blocker tetrodotoxin (TTX), the frequency of miniature GABAergic events is extremely low, rendering difficult their accurate characterization (between <0.01 Hz and 0.027 Hz; Lin and Bergles 2004; Vélez-Fort and others 2010). However, the frequency of these events can be enhanced by bath application of the potent secretagogue ruthenium red, confirming the occurrence of spontaneous fusion of vesicles containing GABA (Lin and Bergles 2004; Vélez-Fort and others 2010).

In addition to electrophysiological experiments, Lin and Bergles (2004) showed the presence of putative morphological presynaptic GABAergic synaptic contacts on OPCs of young and adult rats. Confocal analysis of immunostainings against GAD65 and NG2 showed fluorescent punctata in close apposition with proximal and distal processes of OPCs. These morphological data were corroborated by electron microscopy (EM) that revealed synaptic specializations with presynaptic and postsynaptic dense material and pleomorph vesicles characteristic of a GABAergic terminal (Lin and Bergles 2004). However, it is not clear which age was used for EM studies. Also, quantification of the synapses in OPCs has never been performed, leaving without confirmation the existence of true functional GABAergic synapses throughout life.

Our recent data challenge the idea of the existence of GABAergic synapses in OPCs of the mature brain (Vélez-Fort and others 2010). In this study, we investigated potential developmental changes of GABAergic synaptic transmission of OPCs in the somatosensory cortex during the period of active myelination of the neocortex, that is, the first postnatal month. We demonstrated that direct GABAergic synaptic inputs of OPCs are lost early in postnatal development (after the second postnatal week) and replaced by an extrasynaptic mode of communication, mediated solely by local GABA spillover, that allows interneurons to induce phasic responses in target cells (Figs. 2C and 3). It is important to note that no tonic GABAergic current is apparent in OPCs of brain slices, indicating that extrasynaptic communication with interneurons is not caused by ambient GABA (Lin and Bergles 2004; Vélez-Fort and others 2010). Tanaka and others (2009) also recorded GABAergic spontaneous and evoked currents in NG2+/nestin+ cells of the adult neocortex. Although these authors assumed that recorded currents were induced by GABA release from synapses directly contacting OPCs, the slow rise times of these events are incompatible with fast synaptic transmission (4.7 ms for spontaneous events). These observations and our results are in favor of an extrasynaptic mode of communication between interneurons and OPCs in the adult neocortex (Figs. 2C, 3C, 3D). The postnatal switch from synaptic to extrasynaptic transmission suggests that the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying interneuron–OPC signaling are developmentally regulated. In this respect, it would be interesting to analyze the morphological reorganization of GABAergic innervation as well as the redistribution, if this occurs, of GABAA receptors during cortical postnatal development. Another intriguing aspect of GABAergic signaling into OPCs is the identity of the interneurons innervating these cells. Indeed, neocortical interneurons are a highly heterogeneous cell population that consists of discrete classes playing distinct functions, one of which could be to control OPC activity. Finally, it is not known whether either synaptic or extrasynaptic signaling activates GABAB receptors in brain slices. Indeed, GABAergic currents evoked by low-frequency stimulations are completely blocked by GABAA receptor antagonists (Lin and Bergles 2004; Vélez-Fort and others 2010), and trains of stimulation have been done in the presence of the GABAB receptor antagonist CGP55845 (Vélez-Fort and others 2010).

sec.title: Multiple Roles of Neuron-to-OPC GABAergic Signaling
sec.p: The best-known effect of GABAA receptor activation on OPCs at the cellular level is its ability to depolarize and induce elevations of the intracellular Ca2+ concentration (Fig. 2C). Primary experiments performed in cell culture showed that bath applications of GABA lead to intracellular Ca2+ increases that are inhibited by the N-type VGCC blocker nifedipine (Kirchhoff and Kettenmann 1992). In acute slices of gray and white matter, GABAA receptor activation also induces intracellular Ca2+ increases in both young and adult mice (Bernstein and others 1996; Tanaka and others 2009; Vélez-Fort and others 2010). In addition, perforated patch recordings of OPCs revealed that GABAA receptor–mediated currents have a reversal potential of −44 mV in the young hippocampus (Lin and Bergles 2004) and of −30 mV in the adult neocortex (Tanaka and others 2009). Therefore, GABA is likely an excitatory rather than an inhibitory neurotransmitter for OPCs. Nevertheless, the mechanisms responsible for GABA-dependent intracellular Ca2+ elevations have not been completely elucidated in acute slices. Two controversial mechanisms have been recently proposed. As initially described in cell culture, Tanaka and others (2009) showed that bath applications of GABAA receptor agonists induce a membrane depolarization of OPCs that is sufficient to enable the activation of VGCCs (Fig. 2C). However, Tong and others (2009) suggest that instead of activating these channels, GABAA receptor–dependent depolarization activates a persistent Na+ current, which in turn induces a Ca2+ influx through type 1 NCX (Fig. 2C). Based on the present knowledge, it is difficult to know whether both mechanisms coexist in OPCs in vivo.

GABA-dependent intracellular Ca2+ increases have been observed in OPCs recorded in different preparations, but the required conditions to induce these increases physiologically have not been established. First, the resting potential of these cells is highly hyperpolarized, and the low frequency and amplitude of spontaneous and evoked synaptic currents suggest that the threshold of N-type VGCCs is not easily reached during synaptic activity. In addition, a single OPC is likely contacted by few GABAergic terminals, limiting the cross-talk among GABA release sites. Finally, trains of extracellular stimulation do not elicit detectable Ca2+ signals in the soma of neocortical OPCs loaded with Oregon Green BAPTA1-AM (Vélez-Fort and others 2010). Two-photon Ca2+ imaging experiments combined with neuronal stimulation would help to determine whether intracellular Ca2+ elevations occur locally at the level of cell processes.

GABAergic inputs may influence oligodendrogenesis and thus brain myelination by controlling OPC activity. Consistent with this idea, the frequency of spontaneous GABAergic synaptic events in cortical OPCs is higher during the second postnatal week (Fig. 3A, 3B; Vélez-Fort and others 2010), when the production of premyelinating oligodendrocytes reaches a peak (Baracskay and others 2002). Although no evidence demonstrating a role of these receptors in OPC differentiation exists, it is important to note that GABAergic excitation promotes differentiation of neuronal hippocampal progenitors, presumably through the action of direct synaptic inputs from interneurons (Tozuka and others 2005). In these progenitors, the antagonist of VGCCs Ni2+ decreases the GABA-dependent induction of the transcription factor NeuroD, a positive modulator of neuronal differentiation, suggesting that GABAA receptor–mediated depolarization acts via VGCCs and regulates neurogenesis (Tozuka and others 2005). By analogy with neuronal progenitors, it is conceivable that GABA, probably released at synapses directly contacting OPCs in vivo, induces local intracellular Ca2+ increases and a subsequent production of transcription factors essential for differentiation. Nevertheless, if GABAergic transmission promotes differentiation, this phenomenon is probably restricted to certain brain areas such as hippocampus, neocortex, and white matter cerebellum (Jabs and others 2005; Karadottir and others 2008; Lin and Bergles 2004; Vélez-Fort and others 2010) rather than the optic nerve or other white matter regions where no GABAergic signaling to OPCs has been reported to date. Also, if GABAergic signaling favors differentiation, it should not inhibit cell proliferation. Indeed, proliferating OPCs keep their GABAA receptor–mediated synapses during cell division and transfer them to their progeny (Kukley and others 2008).

(A) Whole-cell recordings of two OPCs held at −90 mV at PN9 (A1) and PN24 (A2) in CsCl-based intracellular solution. Spontaneous synaptic currents are recognized by their fast rise times (<2.1 ms). (B) Plot of spontaneous synaptic current frequency against PN day showing the dramatic decrease of synaptic activity after PN13. It is noteworthy that more than 90% of this activity is GABAergic and no miniature GABAergic currents are detected in these cells at late developmental stages (not shown). (C) Evoked GABAergic currents in OPCs during the first postnatal month. A single pulse stimulation of neuronal fibers elicited inward currents in two OPCs held at −70 mV at PN10 (C1) and PN23 (C2) in control (black) and in the presence of the low-affinity competitive antagonist of GABAA receptors TPMPA (100 µM; red). Note the slow rise time and the stronger inhibition of the current at PN23 with respect to PN10. These results show that the concentration of GABA reaching GABAA receptors in OPCs of older mice is probably lower than that reaching synaptic receptors, indicating that these receptors are extrasynaptic. Indeed, the slow current kinetics are not compatible with a synaptic activation of the receptors. Also, the strong sensitivity for the low-affinity antagonist in the fourth PN week suggests that GABA diffuses over a significant distance. These experiments were performed in the presence of 10 µM NBQX and 50 µM D-AP5. (D) Different cumulative probabilities of rise times for cells in the second (blue) and fourth (black) PN weeks (P < 0.001). The inset shows superimposed normalized averaged currents of two OPCs held at −70 mV at PN11 (blue) and PN24 (black) obtained with single pulse stimulation in the presence of 10 µM NBQX and 50 µM D-AP5. Stimulus artifacts were blanked for visibility; the time of stimulation is indicated with an arrowhead. Adapted from Vélez-Fort and others (2010).

sec.p: Among other roles played by GABAergic signals, GABA probably promotes OPC migration through the activation of GABAA receptors. By using a small-interfering RNA (siRNA) approach, Tong and others (2009) showed that the inhibition of NCX1 expression blocks GABA-induced migration of purified OPCs and of OPCs of brain explants. Their results suggest that GABA-mediated effects depend on Ca2+ influx through the reverse action of NCX1, an alternative pathway to VGCCs, that may occur early in the developing brain. Luyt and others (2007) recently proposed a function of GABAB receptors in OPC migration, but their results are less convincing because receptor activation induces migration in a transwell-based assay but not in an agarose drop migration assay. However, if GABAA receptors are involved in OPC differentiation and migration, GABAB receptors may have a role in proliferation. Indeed, GABAB receptor activation by the selective agonist baclofen dramatically increases the percentage of proliferating OPCs in cell culture via a reduction of cAMP levels (Luyt and others 2007).

GABAergic signaling is an attractive pathway to regulate proliferation, differentiation, and migration of OPCs. However, a large population of OPCs persist in the normal mature brain, even when physiological myelination is complete and migration is no longer required. In addition, electrophysiological properties of OPCs suffer dramatic changes during postnatal development (Maldonado and others 2011; Vélez-Fort and others 2010; Zhou and others 2006), suggesting that these cells constitute distinct cell populations in young and adult animals. As for synaptic activity of OPCs in the young brain, the function of extrasynaptic GABAergic transmission relying on local GABA spillover at a mature stage is intriguing (Vélez-Fort and others 2010). We can speculate that GABAergic input in the absence of synapses allows interneurons to prevent OPC transition to a premyelinating stage, allowing OPCs to play other roles in the normal adult brain, different from that of progenitors. Interestingly, Markwardt and others (2009) described slow GABAA receptor–mediated events in newborn generated granule cells of the adult hippocampus, before neuronal maturation is complete, that resemble those observed in cortical OPCs at the end of the first postnatal month (Vélez-Fort and others 2010). This extrasynaptic GABAergic mode of communication thus constitutes a feature of several immature cells of the normal adult brain. After a demyelinating lesion, however, GABAergic signals may also influence the reactivation of OPCs to induce either their migration or their proliferation/differentiation in the injured tissue. In this respect, it would be interesting to test whether demyelinated axons induce the ex novo formation of functional GABAergic synapses in OPCs of the mature gray matter, as suggested for glutamatergic signaling of migrating OPCs toward corpus callosum during a demyelinated lesion (Etxeberria and others 2010). Tanaka and others (2009) recently suggested that among other potential roles of GABA in pathological conditions, GABAA receptor–mediated excitation in NG2+/nestin+ cells plays a neuroprotective role in the mature brain after ischemic stroke. An increase level of the brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) protein is detected in these cells two days after ischemia and blocked by the inhibitor of NKCC1 transporter bumetanide. Because NKCC1 maintained high [Cl−]i, the effect of bumetanide suggests that a chloride-dependent depolarization, probably through GABAA receptor activation, promotes the production of BDNF and the recovery of somatosensory dysfunctions.

sec.title: Concluding Remarks
sec.p: The first experiments that attempted to demonstrate the existence of GABAergic signals on glial cells started early in the 1980s. More recent achievements have shown that GABAergic signals on glial cells which are “excitatory” rather than inhibitory involve GABAA and GABAB receptors, synaptic and extrasynaptic transmission modes, and different intracellular pathways. However, despite the combined efforts accumulated over the last years, our understanding of the signaling mechanisms mediated by GABA in glial cells is still poor. One important challenge for future investigations in the field of neuron–glia interactions will be to unravel the consequences of glial cell activation by GABAergic signals on brain function in physiological and pathological conditions.
